articles.headline: Trump Moves to Ease the Firing of Federal Workers
articles.snippet: The president aims to peel back labor protections and curb the power of government unions, which assailed the actions.
articles.abstract: The president aims to peel back labor protections and curb the power of government unions, which assailed the actions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seizing on a longtime ambition of many Republicans, President Trump on Friday overhauled rules affecting at least two million federal workers, making it easier to fire them and rolling back the workplace role of their unions.

articles.headline: Banks Tried to Curb Gun Sales. Now Republicans Are Trying to Stop Them.
articles.snippet: Since a few big banks restricted financing for the gun industry, some lawmakers — many of them Wall Street allies — are looking for ways to squelch what they see as social activism.
articles.abstract: Since a few big banks restricted financing for the gun industry, some lawmakers — many of them Wall Street allies — are looking for ways to squelch what they see as social activism.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Congress decided not to take significant action after a spate of mass shootings this year and last, some big banks opted to take matters into their own hands by restricting financing for gun sellers.

articles.headline: Keeping Summit Hopes Alive Suggests Kim Jong-un May Need a Deal
articles.snippet: When President Trump canceled their meeting, Mr. Kim’s bid to ease sanctions and rebuild the North Korean economy was thrown into doubt.
articles.abstract: When President Trump canceled their meeting, Mr. Kim’s bid to ease sanctions and rebuild the North Korean economy was thrown into doubt.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Ever since Kim Jong-un took over as the young, untested ruler of North Korea seven years ago, he has promised his country a future free from deprivation.

articles.headline: How Boston Is Trying to Close the Gender Pay Gap
articles.snippet: Through pay-negotiation workshops and partnerships with more than 100 companies, the city is trying to help female workers match the salaries of male counterparts.
articles.abstract: Through pay-negotiation workshops and partnerships with more than 100 companies, the city is trying to help female workers match the salaries of male counterparts.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a cold, sunny morning in April, Boston’s mayor, Martin J. Walsh, took the podium in front of an audience of 150 corporate executives who had gathered at a downtown hotel to learn how men can be better allies to women at work. He quickly launched into one of his favorite stories, about a woman who approached him in an elevator to thank him for her recent $20,000 pay raise.

articles.headline: Democrats Go All-Out to Avoid Disaster in California House Races
articles.snippet: The party and allied groups are spending more than $4 million on a handful of chaotic congressional races that are critical to Democrats’ strategy to win the House in November.
articles.abstract: The party and allied groups are spending more than $4 million on a handful of chaotic congressional races that are critical to Democrats’ strategy to win the House in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sign up for California Today for the latest news on the June 5 primary and more here.

articles.headline: Ireland Votes to End Abortion Ban, in Rebuke to Catholic Conservatism
articles.snippet: The referendum was the latest sign of a drift toward liberalism in a country that only recently installed a gay man as prime minister and allowed same-sex marriage.
articles.abstract: The referendum was the latest sign of a drift toward liberalism in a country that only recently installed a gay man as prime minister and allowed same-sex marriage.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Ireland voted decisively to repeal one of the world’s more restrictive abortion bans, sweeping aside generations of conservative patriarchy and dealing the latest in a series of stinging rebukes to the Roman Catholic Church.

articles.headline: Trump Versus Law Enforcement: A Confrontation With No Precedent
articles.snippet: The president’s allies say he has every right to manage the executive branch and every reason to be outraged at possible misconduct aimed at his campaign. Critics say he is wreaking untold damage on institutions that form the bulwark of a democrat...
articles.abstract: The president’s allies say he has every right to manage the executive branch and every reason to be outraged at possible misconduct aimed at his campaign. Critics say he is wreaking untold damage on institutions that form the bulwark of a democratic society.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a White House meeting last winter, leaders of the F.B.I. and the Justice Department made an urgent appeal to John F. Kelly, the White House chief of staff, to side with them against Republicans in Congress who were pressing for information about the Russia investigation that would compromise confidential sources.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Katie Benner

articles.headline: The Evangelical Fight to Win Back California
articles.snippet: As the primary approaches, Franklin Graham brings Jesus — and a conservative political message — to a state with a vast pool of evangelical voters.
articles.abstract: As the primary approaches, Franklin Graham brings Jesus — and a conservative political message — to a state with a vast pool of evangelical voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — Franklin Graham stood in a packed locker room at the Rose Bowl, surrounded by fellow evangelists, pastors, and his top Los Angeles donors. It was two weeks before the California primary, and Mr. Graham was urging them to take a stand against their state’s “blue wall.”

articles.headline: U.S. and North Korean Officials Race to Resurrect Trump-Kim Meeting
articles.snippet: American diplomats made a rare visit to North Korea as officials sought to dispel skepticism about the chances of reaching a framework for a deal in such a short time.
articles.abstract: American diplomats made a rare visit to North Korea as officials sought to dispel skepticism about the chances of reaching a framework for a deal in such a short time.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and North Korea on Sunday kicked off an urgent, behind-the-scenes effort to resurrect a summit meeting between their two leaders by June 12, racing to develop a joint agenda and dispel deep skepticism about the chances for reaching a framework for a lasting nuclear agreement in so little time.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: More Jobs Will Be Cleared for Takeoff. Aspiring Pilots Are Ready.
articles.snippet: As big airlines face a wave of retirements, a fresh batch of fliers gets a chance, and the training, to seize the opportunity.
articles.abstract: As big airlines face a wave of retirements, a fresh batch of fliers gets a chance, and the training, to seize the opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michelle Hynds was working at a security job seven years ago when she began to take flight lessons at an airport near Ventura, Calif.
articles.byline: By Zach Wichter and Micah Maidenberg

articles.headline: As Ireland Joins Europe’s Sprint From Catholic Fold, Francis Looks South
articles.snippet: Pope Francis, who seems resigned that a devout and Catholic Europe has largely slipped into the church’s past, has shifted his focus to the world’s outcasts.
articles.abstract: Pope Francis, who seems resigned that a devout and Catholic Europe has largely slipped into the church’s past, has shifted his focus to the world’s outcasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — When nearly one-third of Ireland’s Catholic population came to see Pope John Paul II celebrate a papal Mass in Dublin in 1979, divorce, homosexual acts and abortion were all illegal in the country. Ireland, like much of Europe, toed the line on Roman Catholic Church teaching.

articles.headline: The Next Privacy Battle in Europe Is Over This New Law
articles.snippet: The tech industry is fighting a pending measure that’s even stricter than the recently enacted G.D.P.R. It’s called the ePrivacy Regulation.
articles.abstract: The tech industry is fighting a pending measure that’s even stricter than the recently enacted G.D.P.R. It’s called the ePrivacy Regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The new European data privacy legislation is so stringent that it could kill off data-driven online services and chill innovations like driverless cars, tech industry groups warn.

articles.headline: Fidelity, Bruised From Crises, Searches for Life After Mutual Funds
articles.snippet: Led by its founder’s granddaughter, the investment giant is focusing on more mundane business lines as it also assesses its corporate culture.
articles.abstract: Led by its founder’s granddaughter, the investment giant is focusing on more mundane business lines as it also assesses its corporate culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Few star fund managers have shone brighter than Steven S. Wymer, who runs a portfolio of stocks at Fidelity Investments, the mutual-fund giant.

articles.headline: In Britain, Austerity Is Changing Everything
articles.snippet: After eight years of budget cutting, Britain is looking less like the rest of Europe and more like the United States, with a shrinking welfare state and spreading poverty.
articles.abstract: After eight years of budget cutting, Britain is looking less like the rest of Europe and more like the United States, with a shrinking welfare state and spreading poverty.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRESCOT, England — A walk through this modest town in the northwest of England amounts to a tour of the casualties of Britain’s age of austerity.

articles.headline: Arlington Cemetery, Nearly Full, May Become More Exclusive
articles.snippet: To preserve space for future war heroes in the country’s premier national cemetery, the Army is considering new rules that would turn away many currently eligible veterans.
articles.abstract: To preserve space for future war heroes in the country’s premier national cemetery, the Army is considering new rules that would turn away many currently eligible veterans.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — The solemn ritual of a burial with military honors is repeated dozens of times a day, in foul weather or fair, at Arlington National Cemetery, honoring service members from privates to presidents. But in order to preserve the tradition of burial at the nation’s foremost military cemetery for future generations, the Army, which runs Arlington, says that it may have to deny it to nearly all veterans who are living today.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps and Damon Winter

articles.headline: Paris ‘Spider-Man’ Saves Young Boy. Cue Debate on Migrants.
articles.snippet: Mamoudou Gassama, from Mali, crawled up several balconies to pull the child to safety. The French president said Mr. Gassama would be granted legal status.
articles.abstract: Mamoudou Gassama, from Mali, crawled up several balconies to pull the child to safety. The French president said Mr. Gassama would be granted legal status.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The 4-year-old boy seemed to be suspended from a balcony. An adult standing on a nearby balcony seemed powerless to help. Disaster seemed the only possible outcome.
articles.byline: By Aurelien Breeden and Alan Cowell

articles.headline: Uber’s Exit From Southeast Asia Upsets Regulators and Drivers
articles.snippet: Uber abruptly sold its ride-hailing operations to its top competitor, creating a virtual monopoly in the region and daring regulators to stop it.
articles.abstract: Uber abruptly sold its ride-hailing operations to its top competitor, creating a virtual monopoly in the region and daring regulators to stop it.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — In a new television ad, Uber’s chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi, pledges to move the ride-hailing giant beyond its bad-boy past. “One of our core values as a company is to always do the right thing,” declares Mr. Khosrowshahi, who joined the business nine months ago.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Weiyi Lim

articles.headline: Italian President’s Loyalty to the Euro Creates Chaos
articles.snippet: President Sergio Mattarella enraged populists, who called for his impeachment, by rejecting a cabinet minister he feared would lead Italy out of the eurozone.
articles.abstract: President Sergio Mattarella enraged populists, who called for his impeachment, by rejecting a cabinet minister he feared would lead Italy out of the eurozone.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — He’s been called “gray,” “invisible” and “gentle to the point of seeming fragile.” Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister, once compared him to “a monk.”

articles.headline: Think the Big Banks Have Abandoned Coal? Think Again
articles.snippet: An environmental group’s analysis shows the five largest United States banks have started lending to coal companies again now that they’re out of bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: An environmental group’s analysis shows the five largest United States banks have started lending to coal companies again now that they’re out of bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starting three years ago, the largest American banks vowed to cut back on lending to the coal industry.
